column1: Math Talk: Improving Problem Solving Skills Using Supported Communication
column2: This study seeks to test the effectiveness of a set of lesson plans focused on  probability skills and concepts. Instruction will involve supported discussion about probability problems to strengthen students' reasoning and communication skills.
column3: Children aged 8-12 with autism, verbal communication ability, and basic mathematics skills, including the ability to solve simple computation problems (e.g., 5 + 9 = 14, and 5 x 5 = 25).
column4: Students will receive a $100.00 gift card for participating in the study. Your participation in this project will help us learn to better support the communication needs of students with autism to improve their performance in mathematical problem solving.

column1: Parent-Child Brain Synchrony in Autism Spectrum Disorders
column2: This study seeks to learn more about how parents and children's brains work to relate to one another during social activities. Participation involves attending two study appointments at UVA, during which you and your child will play games and complete some testing.
column3: Children aged 6-11 years with our without autism and one parent.
column4: Parents will receive $80 for completion of both visits, and children will receive a small prize.
column8: How do the brains of children with autism and their parents work to relate to one another during social activities?
column12: Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Education and Human Development
column16: Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Education and Human Development

column1: PEERS Social Skills Intervention for Adolescent Girls with Autism Spectrum Disorder
column2: This study seeks to learn more about how the PEERS intervention program can be used to support social skill and friendship development in teen girls with Autism Spectrum Disorder. Participation involves attending one initial testing appointment, ten weekly social skills group sessions, and a post-program appointment to complete questionnaires. The PEERS program provides social skills instruction and practice for teen girls as well as coaching sessions for the girls' parents.
column3: Adolescent females ages 11-17 who attend middle or high school. Adolescents must have average language ability and cognitive ability for their age. A parent must be able to participate in all group sessions. Parents and teens must be able to attend at least 8 of the 10 group sessions. Adolescents must NOT have significant behavioral difficulty or mental health disorder (e.g., schizophrenia) that prevents them from being able to participate in group sessions effectively.
column4: Participants will receive $50 for completing the initial appointment, $20 for each group session attended, and $50 for completing the post-program appointment. (Max total compensation=$300) Girls and their parents may also learn skills useful for improving their social skills and friendships. This study will help us better understand how the PEERS intervention can help support teen girls' social skills when provided in an all-female group format and tailored to the needs of girls with ASD.
column6: UVA Sheila Johnson Center for Human Services (Bavaro Hall)

column1: Function-Based Video Self-Modeling to the Treat Disruptive Behavior of Individuals with Autism.
column2: For students who have had minimal success on current behavior plans, this study explored the effects of using applied behavior analysis procedures to inform a video self-modeling treatment. Participants starred in their own movie, portraying appropriate behavior amidst conditions that typically triggered disruptive behavior. Participation involved watching the video 1 time per day and completing their regular classroom activities.
column3: Individuals with autism aged 3 to 45 years old. Individuals who are unable to attend to a video screen for at least 30 seconds (e.g., computer, tablet) will be excluded.
column4: Immediate benefits include access to a video starring the individual that can be accessed on a phone, tablet, or computer. The long-term benefits of this project are a decrease in problem behavior and an increase in appropriate behavior
column6: This project takes place at the Virginia Institute of Autism, school, outpatient clinic, and adult services.

column1: Feasibility of Using a New Behavior Analytic Procedure (Interview Informed Synthesized Contingency Analysis [IISCA]) to Inform Treatment Decisions
column2: Disruptive behavior in adults with autism is difficult to manage due to long reinforcement histories. This project aimed to decrease disruptive behavior and increase social engagement for adults with autism using an applied behavior analysis procedure. Participants will be observed under conditions that typically trigger problem behavior and positive reinforcement will be provided.
column3: Individuals with autism and/or developmental disabilities aged 3 to 45. Individuals without problem behavior will be excluded.
column4: Benefits include a detailed analysis of why problem behavior occurs and an intervention specifically tailored to increase communication and social opportunities.
column6: This study will take place at the Virginia Institute of Autism, school, outpatient behavior clinic, and adult services.
column16: Ph.D., BCBA-D, Clinical Director of the Virginia Institute of Autism

column1: Improving Compliance with Dental Examinations for Individuals with Autism
column2: Dental examinations are an essential part of preventative health services. Lack of appropriate dental care can have detrimental health-related consequences, as well associated discomfort. The intervention consists of gradually introducing the steps of the dental examination and will include basic dental hygiene and simulated x-rays.
column3: Individuals with autism aged 5 to 45. Exclusion criteria includes individuals who do not demonstrate disruptive behavior during dental examinations.
column4: Benefits of this project include dental cleanings and examinations from a local dentist at no charge. Long term benefits include improved oral health.
column6: Sessions will take place at the Virginia Institute of Autism, out-patient behavior clinic and Children's Dentistry of Charlottesville.
column8: Can gradually introducing the steps of the dental exam to patients with autism help reduce disruptive behavior during visits to the dentist?
column16: Ph.D., BCBA-D, Clinical Director of the Virginia Institute of Autism

column1: Snack Talks: Increasing Social Interactions During Mealtimes for Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder
column2: Mealtimes are an important commonly occurring routine in homes, schools, and the community. This study explores the use of a social communication support to increase child-to-child communication during mealtimes in classroom settings. Implementation of this intervention aims to increase engagement and communication with peers, as well as decrease engagement in challenging behavior.
column3: Preschoolers diagnosed with autism. Adults diagnosed with autism.
column4: Your participation in this project will help us better understand how to best promote social communication during mealtimes for children and adults with autism.
column6: Faison Center, Richmond, VA, Virginia Institute of Autism, Charlottesville, VA

column1: Teaching Social Skills to Children with Autism in Elementary School
column2: This study seeks to increase social skills and friendships for children with autism in elementary school.
column3: Children diagnosed with autism in elementary school.
column4: Your participation in this project will help us better understand effective teaching strategies to support children with autism in navigating social situations.

column1: Therapeutic and diagnostic potential of targeting microRNAs in autism
column2: The study seeks to understand the mechanism of how parental and gestational exposure to environmental factors contribute to autism. Based on preliminary evidence, we hypothesize that the transgenerational transmission of autism traits is programmed by small non-coding RNAs such as microRNA. In this study, we will define the microRNA expression signature in a mouse model of Maternal-Immune-Activation (MIA)-induced autism, and interrogate a functional role for microRNA dysregulation in autism.
column12: Ph.D., Professor, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics
column16: Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Department of Neuroscience
column20: Ph.D., Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics

column1: Water Safety in Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
column2: This study is investigating whether community-based swim instructors can be effectively teach water safety skills to children with autism spectrum disorder using behavioral skills training.
column3: Children aged 6 - 22 years who cannot swim and who are enrolled or were recently enrolled in services through the Virginia Institute of Autism. Children who cannot tolerate getting into water, have a neurological condition that preclude them from entering water, or who are not toilet trained will be excluded.
column4: Participants will be learning potentially life-saving water safety skills.
column12: Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Education and Human Development
column16: Ph.D., BCBA-D, Clinical Director of the Virginia Institute of Autism

column2: This study seeks to validate multiple observation-based, level 2 screeners designed to identify children at risk of later being diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder.
column3: Children ages 1 - 18 years without a previous diagnosis, who are being evaluated for concerns of autism spectrum disorder through the UVA Health System.
column4: Participants and their families will receive a small monetary incentive for their participation. Your participation in this project will also help us further develop and refine tools that can be used to assist diagnosticians' clinical decision making during an autism diagnostic evaluation.
column6: UVA Sheila Johnson Clinic and UVA Health System

column1: Efficacy and Acceptability of Abbreviated Direct Assessment Procedures in Schools
column2: This study seeks to compare the acceptability and efficacy of short direct assessment procedures in identifying the functions of, or reasons behind, problem behavior in a school setting.
column3: Children enrolled in services at the Virginia Institute of Autism who have not previously undergone a Functional Behavior Assessment.
column4: Participants will be provided a small monetary incentive. Data will be used to aid instructors and therapists at the Virginia Institute of Autism to develop future behavior intervention plans.
column12: Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Education and Human Development

column1: Improving ASD Clinic-Based Instruments: An Innovative Approach
column2: This study seeks to develop new innovative software to analyze data collected using tests, questionnaires and tasks currently used in ASD research projects and clinical practice. The goal is to check the quality of these instruments, improving the way they are used. It is also a goal of this study to develop an online app that clinicians and researchers can use to analyze their own datasets.
column6: Department of Psychology, University of Virginia.
column12: Assistant Professor of Quantitative Methods, Department of Psychology
column16: Associate Professor of Psychology, Department of Psychology

column1: Longitudinal Study on Reading, Writing, Social, and Cognitive Development of Young Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
column2: The purpose of this study is to learn about how young children (4-6 year olds) with and without autism spectrum disorder develop in their reading and writing abilities across a three-year period. Participation involves a 2-3 hour study appointment once a year for three years that will include a variety of games and tests that involve the use of reading, writing, social, and cognitive abilities. Participating families will receive compensation following each study appointment.
column3: Children must be between the ages of 4 and 6 at the beginning of the study. Children with autism spectrum disorder must already have a community diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder. Exclusionary criteria includes an identified syndrome other than autism spectrum disorder (e.g., Fragile X), an intellectual disability, significant sensory or motor impairment (e.g., visual impairments), a neurological disorder (e.g., epilepsy, cerebral palsy), psychotic symptoms (e.g., hallucinations or delusions), or any major medical disorder that could be associated with extended absences from school.
column4: Participating families will receive a $20 UVA check following each designated assessment visit. Your participation will contribute to better understanding the course of learning and development in school-age children with autism spectrum disorder and may potentially lead to the development of new instructional methods through which schools can best facilitate the development of subsequent generations of students with autism spectrum disorder.
column6: Local schools and community locations in Charlottesville and at the University of Virginia.
column8: How do young children with and without autism spectrum disorder develop in their reading and writing abilities?

column1: Is late diagnosis of autism in rural areas of Virginia related to missed well child checks?
column2: We are using a state-level database of Virginia children's insurance claims to determine if children who live in rural communities are more likely to miss well-child checks prior to kindergarten. Next, we are looking at the association of those missed visits with late diagnosis of autism.
column3: This study uses an existing dataset of children living in Virginia from 2011-2016.
column6: This is a secondary data study.
column12: PhD, RN, Associate Professor of Nursing
column13: University of Virginia School of Nursing

column1: Parent Coaching: Increasing Quality of Life for Children and Families Affected by Autism Spectrum Disorder
column2: This study seeks to teach parents behavioral strategies to prevent and respond to challenging behavior.
column3: Parents of children diagnosed with autism within the last 12 months.
column4: Your participation in the project will help us better understand how to effectively support parents of children with autism to increase quality of life for all family members.
